description: From Middle English swilen (“to wash; swirl; wash away”), from Old English swillan, swilian (“to wash; wash down; swill; gargle”), from Proto-West Germanic *swilljan, from Proto-Germanic *swiljaną (“to gulp, swallow”), from Proto-Indo-European *swel- (“to drink, gulp, swallow”). Related to English swallow.

entries.meaning: (collective) A mixture of solid and liquid food scraps fed to pigs etc; especially kitchen waste for this purpose.
(by extension) Any disgusting or distasteful liquid.
examples: I cannot believe anyone could drink this swill.

entries.meaning: (by extension, figurative) Anything disgusting or worthless.
examples: This new TV show is a worthless load of swill.

entries.meaning: (informal) A large quantity of liquid drunk at one swallow.
examples: He took a swill of his drink and tried to think of words.

verbs.description: swill (third-person singular simple present swills, present participle swilling, simple past and past participle swilled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To drink (or, rarely, eat) greedily or to excess.
examples: O’Malley answered calmly as he shoved half of the pie into his mouth.
“Stop! Stop—swilling that pie!” the colonel roared.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To wash (something) by flooding with water.
(transitive) To move (a liquid or liquid-filled vessel) in a circular motion.
examples: Jimmie looked lovingly at the flask, smelt it, and then, placing it next his ear, swilled it round to hear the splash of liquor.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a liquid) To move around or over a surface.
examples: […]  before them, between the high banks of the Vaal, they saw only a world of brown water, streaked with white froth, hurling down upon them. It rose above the foot-board and swilled to the level of the seat.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To inebriate; to fill with drink.
examples: Have I not kept open house for three days and nights, and swilled yourself and comrades with liquor for a week, and haven’t you all been drunk at my expense for several days?
